title: 106_hr1829
content: The Air Force plays a role in managing the Civil Air Patrol as a civilian auxiliary of the Air Force. The Air Force manages the Civil Air Patrol as a federally chartered corporation and volunteer civilian auxiliary. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force administers the Civil Air Patrol under the Secretary of the Air Force's direction. The Secretary appoints a National Board of Directors composed of Air Force general officers and senior civilian employees. The National Board of Directors for the Civil Air Patrol is appointed, consisting of Air Force general officers, senior civilian employees, and volunteer members. The chairman is the senior active duty Air Force officer. The Board appoints a National Commander, Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General. These appointees report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the Board. The Civil Air Patrol's National Board of Directors appoints key positions including the National Commander, Executive Director, Safety Officer, and Inspector General. These appointees report directly to the Secretary of the Air Force through the Board. The Chief of Staff of the Air Force can assign officers, enlisted members, and civilian employees to serve at the national headquarters of the Civil Air Patrol. Members appointed or assigned to management positions do not receive compensation. The Civil Air Patrol prohibits active duty members or civilian employees from managing non-Federal entities. Officers or enlisted members in management positions do not receive additional compensation. The Executive Director and National Board of Directors can utilize CAP employees and volunteers for noncombat missions, exempt from federal employment laws. The Civil Air Patrol assists the Department of the Air Force in noncombat missions. Members and employees are not considered Federal employees and are exempt from federal employment laws. Funds provided to the Civil Air Patrol are subject to federal regulations governing appropriated funds to private, nonprofit organizations. The Civil Air Patrol, under certain sections of the law, must adhere to federal regulations regarding the provision of funds to private, nonprofit organizations. Additionally, the powers granted to the Civil Air Patrol are subject to approval by the Secretary of the Air Force. The Air Force plays a role in management and receives assistance from other agencies.
